dataRow.name: Zuckerman Institute for Connective Environmental Research
dataRow.description: The Zuckerman Institute for Connective Environmental Research (ZICER) is home to international research centres, the Tyndall Centre for Climate Change, CSERGE and the Centre for Environmental Risk. The ZICER building itself is also a innovation in environmental friendly architecture.

dataRow.name: Climatic Research Unit
dataRow.description: The Climatic Research Unit, part of the School of Environmental Sciences, is widely recognised as one of the world's leading institutions concerned with the study of natural and anthropogenic climate change.

dataRow.name: INTO University of East Anglia
dataRow.description: INTO University of East Anglia is a state of the art, purpose built Centre, which prepares international students for entry onto degree courses at the University. The Centre comprises modern teaching and accomodation facilities over five stories.

dataRow.name: Norwich Business School
dataRow.description: Norwich Business School embraces the University's motto of ‘Do Different' by delivering innovative and pioneering courses at facilities in both Norwich and London. Our excellent teaching department is underpinned by cutting edge research, which ensures we're highly relevant to business needs now and in the future.

dataRow.name: Norwich Medical School
dataRow.description: The Norwich Medical School is a leader in preparing students to become highly competent and confident doctors. We are proud of our reputation as one of the very best schools of medicine in the country. We want you to be the best too – by learning and developing first class clinical skills and nurturing excellence in scientific understanding.

dataRow.name: Art, Media and American Studies
dataRow.description: The School of Art, Media and American Studies brings together world-leading expertise in the visual arts, in film, television and media studies and in the literature, history, and culture of the United States, and the Atlantic and Pacific worlds.

dataRow.name: School of Biological Sciences
dataRow.description: The School of Biological Sciences is a vibrant and friendly academic community firmly embedded in the internationally renowned Norwich Research Park. It boasts extensive state-of-the-art research facilities as well as modern teaching laboratories.

dataRow.name: School of Chemistry
dataRow.description: The School of Chemistry prides itself on research excellence across its spectrum of activities, from synthetic chemistry and drug discovery to spectroscopy and analytical and biophysical chemistry, as confirmed by successive Research Assessment Exercises.

dataRow.name: School of Computing Sciences
dataRow.description: The School of Computing Sciences is one of the largest and most experienced Schools of Computing Sciences in the UK, expertly blending excellent teaching, research, facilities and exciting course modules to offer a dynamic programme targeted at the job market.

dataRow.name: School of Economics
dataRow.description: The School of Economics proudly combines a reputation for internationally renowned research and unparalleled academic support to its students. Always pursuing a research-inspired approach, we are committed to offering an outstanding academic experience that provides a platform to fully explore the influence of economic analysis.

dataRow.name: School of Education and Lifelong Learning
dataRow.description: The School was ranked joint 3rd for Teaching and joint 5th for overall satisfaction in the 2012 National Student Survey.

dataRow.name: School of Environmental Sciences
dataRow.description: The School of Environmental Sciences is one of the longest established, largest and most fully developed Schools of Environmental Sciences in Europe. Our holistic approach to teaching and research, integrating physical, chemical, biological, social and geotechnical sciences into the study of natural and human environments, is truly a modern philosophy for the new millennium.

dataRow.name: History
dataRow.description: Recognised as a leading department within the UK, History at UEA has a chronological range from the collapse of the Roman empire to the present day, a geographical scope covering Europe, Africa, the Middle East, North America and the Caribbean, and experts in political, economic, social, cultural, environmental, diplomatic and intellectual history.

dataRow.name: School of International Development
dataRow.description: The School of International Development (DEV) at the University of East Anglia is a leading global centre of excellence in research and teaching in international development. Read more about the school.

dataRow.name: Politics, Philosophy, Language and Communication Studies
dataRow.description: The School brings together staff and students studying a wide range of subjects including politics, international relations, broadcast journalism, media, public policy, philosophy, language competency, intercultural communication and translation studies

dataRow.name: Literature, Drama and Creative Writing
dataRow.description: The School of Literature, Drama and Creative Writing at the University of East Anglia has a long-established international reputation in literary studies. World famous for its pioneering courses in creative writing, it is also home to prize-winning scholars and translators of literature and drama from all periods.

dataRow.name: School of Mathematics
dataRow.description: The School of Mathematics at UEA is a flourishing department committed to excellence in teaching and research.

dataRow.name: School of Natural Sciences
dataRow.description: Studying Natural sciences is an ideal way to combine interests from more than one area of science.

dataRow.name: School of Health Sciences
dataRow.description: The School of Health Sciences offers a superb learning environment that enables students to fulfil their potential and ensures our graduates are fit for practice in the modern and ever-changing health and social care sector.

dataRow.name: School of Pharmacy
dataRow.description: The School was founded in 2003 and has quickly risen to become one of the top pharmacy schools in the country, number one in the Guardian University Guide (2013). Our Pharmacy degree is highly acclaimed for its innovative content and teaching methods and was reaccrediated by the GPhC in 2012 with no conditions or recommendations.

dataRow.name: School of Psychology
dataRow.description: We are the first new school of Psychology in a research-intensive UK university for many years, but with an already-thriving British Psychological Society accredited degree programme that is consistently rated most highly by our students. Our teaching is research-led, with internationally-renowned researchers sharing the excitement of new discoveries in psychological science that impact upon how we understand each other and the world in which we live.

dataRow.name: School of Social Work
dataRow.description: The School of Social Work is an internationally renowned academic department dedicated to research and teaching. We have a strong interdisciplinary focus with a reputation for policy relevant empirical research.

dataRow.name: Law School
dataRow.description: The Law School is renowned for its high quality of courses and internationally recognised research, as well as providing an intimate, student focused experience.

dataRow.name: Graduate School
dataRow.description: The Faculty of Social Science (SSF) Graduate School at the University of East Anglia (UEA) provides a vibrant and interdisciplinary research and training environment for postgraduate research (PGR) students.

dataRow.name: Interdisciplinary Institute for the Humanities
dataRow.description: We provide an intellectual home for those activities in the Faculty of Arts and Humanities which cross disciplinary boundaries, including the Centre for Japanese Studies (CJS) and the East Anglian Film Archive (EAFA).

dataRow.name: UEA Library
dataRow.description: The Library plays an important part in the life of every student. The Library contains over 800,000 books and journals, 1,200 study spaces, over 260 computers for student use and 24 hour open access to the IT facility.

dataRow.name: Study Abroad
dataRow.description: The Study Abroad Office has a team of staff dedicated to supporting the needs of all students interested in spending a period abroad either here at UEA or on exchange with one of our partners. We look forward to meeting you in our office.

dataRow.name: International Office
dataRow.description: The University of East Anglia has a student population of 15,000 and is home to more than 3500 students from outside the UK. International students are attracted to our top quality undergraduate (Bachelor) and postgraduate (Masters and PhD) studies in popular subjects ranging from social sciences and humanities to life, natural and health sciences. Our world class academic staff bring the courses to life and help prepare our graduates for a dynamic future.

dataRow.name: Accommodation Office
dataRow.description: Accommodation Office - Nelson Court room 0.353

dataRow.name: Accommodation Office
dataRow.description: Accommodation Office - Nelson Court room 0.353

dataRow.name: Britten House
dataRow.description: Our newest residences, Britten, Browne, Colman, Kett, Paston and Victory all provide light, en-suite rooms grouped in 8 or 12-person flats, with a central wide corridor and a purpose-built kitchen/diner.

dataRow.name: Browne House
dataRow.description: Our newest residences, Britten, Browne, Colman, Kett, Paston and Victory all provide light, en-suite rooms grouped in 8 or 12-person flats, with a central wide corridor and a purpose-built kitchen/diner.

dataRow.name: Colman House (Block G)
dataRow.description: Our newest residences, Britten, Browne, Colman, Kett, Paston and Victory all provide light, en-suite rooms grouped in 8 or 12-person flats, with a central wide corridor and a purpose-built kitchen/diner.

dataRow.name: Colman House (Block F)
dataRow.description: Our newest residences, Britten, Browne, Colman, Kett, Paston and Victory all provide light, en-suite rooms grouped in 8 or 12-person flats, with a central wide corridor and a purpose-built kitchen/diner.

dataRow.name: Constable Terrace
dataRow.description: Constable Terrace offers rooms arranged mainly in ten-person houses, with a large kitchen and dining area on the ground floor.

dataRow.name: Family Accomodation
dataRow.description: UEA owns and maintains 46 two-bedroom, centrally-heated houses, to let to UEA students who have children. For more information please visit Students with families

dataRow.name: Kett House
dataRow.description: Our newest residences, Britten, Browne, Colman, Kett, Paston and Victory all provide light, en-suite rooms grouped in 8 or 12-person flats, with a central wide corridor and a purpose-built kitchen/diner.

dataRow.name: Nelson Court
dataRow.description: Nelson Court offers rooms arranged mainly in ten-person houses, with a large kitchen and dining area on the ground floor.

dataRow.name: Norfolk Terrace
dataRow.description: Rooms in the architecturally unique ziggurats of Norfolk and Suffolk Terrace are arranged in flats of up to 12 rooms, each with own washbasin, and each flat has a large kitchen/diner overlooking the broad. Norfolk and Suffolk terrace have been recently refurbished to upgrade the shower and toilet facilities as well as the study bedrooms.

dataRow.name: Orwell Close
dataRow.description: 100 standard rooms are available in Orwell Close and Wolfson Close. The rooms are arranged in flats of between 5 and 12 rooms, and the size of the kitchen/diner reflects the number of people sharing. Please note these rooms do not have washbasins.

dataRow.name: Paston House
dataRow.description: Our newest residences, Britten, Browne, Colman, Kett, Paston and Victory all provide light, en-suite rooms grouped in 8 or 12-person flats, with a central wide corridor and a purpose-built kitchen/diner.

dataRow.name: Suffolk Terrace
dataRow.description: Rooms in the architecturally unique ziggurats of Norfolk and Suffolk Terrace are arranged in flats of up to 12 rooms, each with own washbasin, and each flat has a large kitchen/diner overlooking the broad. Norfolk and Suffolk terrace have been recently refurbished to upgrade the shower and toilet facilities as well as the study bedrooms.

dataRow.name: University Village
dataRow.description: The University Village, located just across the road from the main University entrance, offers 700 en-suite rooms in a group of 10 buildings, and is popular with students because of its sense of community.

dataRow.name: Victory House
dataRow.description: Our newest residences, Britten, Browne, Colman, Kett, Paston and Victory all provide light, en-suite rooms grouped in 8 or 12-person flats, with a central wide corridor and a purpose-built kitchen/diner.

dataRow.name: Wolfson Close
dataRow.description: 100 standard rooms are available in Orwell Close and Wolfson Close. The rooms are arranged in flats of between 5 and 12 rooms, and the size of the kitchen/diner reflects the number of people sharing. Please note these rooms do not have washbasins.

dataRow.name: BroadView Lodge
dataRow.description: Broadview Lodge is Bed and Breakfast accommodation on campus. Broadview Lodge has sixty en-suite rooms, which are available all year round, ideal for a small conference, training day or indeed for leisure guests. Rooms are equipped with TV, tea and coffee making facilities, Wi-Fi internet access, alarm clock, hair dryer and an iron and ironing board.

dataRow.name: Bob Champion Research and Education Building
The Enterprise Centre (TEC)
dataRow.description: Located at the gateway to the campus, and managed by the Adapt Low Carbon Group, this ground-breaking building is the region's huib for entrepreneurs, innovators and businesses that are committed to building a low carbon future.

dataRow.name: Bluebell Road, adj University Entrance
dataRow.description: Buses from city centre drop off here

dataRow.description: For buses 25, 25A and X25 to Norwich City centre and Rail Station

dataRow.description: For buses towards city centre

dataRow.name: Earlham Road, opp Earlham Park Gates
dataRow.description: For buses: 4,3 to Norwich City centre (bus station)

dataRow.name: Bio Cafe
dataRow.description: Located in the science building, Bio Café is fantastic for barista coffee accompanied with a great range of sandwiches & snacks.

dataRow.name: Cafe Direct
dataRow.description: Café Direct, the powerhouse of high street coffee shops is renowned for its totally spectacular coffee - the very best on campus! Great baguettes and tasty hot snacks are available here too, find us near the bank.
dataRow.openingtimes:
Term time
Monday to Friday 08:00-19:00
Saturday and Sunday 09:30-17:00

Vacation Period
Monday to Friday 09:00-17:00
Saturday and Sunday 09:30-17:00

dataRow.name: Blend
dataRow.description: The Blend is a relaxed coffee and snack bar which offers hot breakfast items, sandwiches, baked items and pizza for lunch. A wide selection of coffees, teas and cold drinks are also available. The Blend is the ideal venue for meeting friends, chatting about a recent lecture or an informal meeting.

dataRow.name: Vista
dataRow.description: Vista is an oasis of tranquility for staff and post graduates alike. Serving superb barista coffee, delicious lunches and tasty afternoon snacks.

dataRow.name: Zest
dataRow.description: Located on the ground floor of The Campus Kitchen found in the main square.
dataRow.openingtimes: Monday - Friday: 07:30am to 20:00pm, Saturday and Sunday: 10:30am to 16:30pm (non-term time Monday - Friday: 07:30am to 18.00pm, closed at the weekends)

dataRow.name: Sportscafe
dataRow.openingtimes:
Monday to Thursday 08:00 to 22:00
Friday to Saturday 08:00 to 21:00
Last food orders 30mins before close

dataRow.name: Tonic
dataRow.description: Located in the Edith Cavell building, Tonic offers fresh, homemade sandwiches, scones and cakes with an array of coffees, teas and soft drinks.
dataRow.openingtimes: Monday to Friday: 8:30am to 15:30pm (closed throughout August)

dataRow.name: Cafe 57
dataRow.description: Cafe 57 is the latest addition to The Campus Kitchen portfolio. We are located in the The Julian Study Centre (Building 57) on Chancellors Drive

dataRow.name: CareerCentral
dataRow.description: The Careers Service provides information, advice and guidance services for all UEA students and graduates, helping them into employment and further study.

dataRow.name: Multifaith Centre
dataRow.description: UEA's Multifaith Centre is a spiritual meeting place and community centre on campus.
dataRow.openingtimes: We are open for staff and students of the University from 10 am to 4 pm, Monday to Friday during semester time and on Sunday evenings for services.

dataRow.name: Islamic Prayer Room
dataRow.description: Islamic Prayer Room located in the main Lecture Theatre Block (opposite Lecture Theatre 2).
dataRow.openingtimes: Open for daily prayers from 6am–11pm every day including weekends, via campus card swipe access

dataRow.name: Islamic Prayer Hall
dataRow.description: The main hall at Blackdale is available for prayers for staff and students on Fridays

dataRow.name: Colney Lane Pavillion
dataRow.description: Colney Lane Pavillion

dataRow.name: Dean of Students' Office
dataRow.description: The Dean of Students' Office offers wide-ranging advice and guidance to any student who is experiencing difficulties or who wishes to make the most of the opportunities available to them at UEA.

dataRow.name: The Nick Rayns LCR
dataRow.description: The Nick Rayns LCR has been voted as the best student venue in the country by the music industry's Live! magazine. Each year it plays host to well known bands such as Public Enemy, Sterephonics, Kasabian, Amy Winehouse and The Ting Tings amongst others. For full LCR listings click LCR Nights

dataRow.name: UEA Nursery
dataRow.description: UEA Nursery is a full day care Nursery offering care for babies from 6 weeks and children until starting school.

dataRow.name: The Lodge (Security)
dataRow.description: The Lodge (Security) provides a 24-hour point of contact for those seeking advice or assistance and to keep the campus safe, security staff maintain close liaison with the local police.

dataRow.name: Sportspark
dataRow.description: The Sportspark is East Anglia's largest swimming and sports centre. It includes an olympic sized swimming pool, an eight lane international standard athletics track, Norfolk's largest indoor climbing wall, a state of the art fitness centre plus much, much more. For a comprehensive list of all the activities offered at the Sportspark, please click the link above.

dataRow.name: Student Union Pub and Bar
dataRow.description: The Union Pub and Bar is the hub of social life on campus. As well as providing the usual pub services; drinks, snacks, games machines, pool tables and a juke box, it also hosts a wide selection of special events - karaoke, tournaments, promotions, DJ sets and more.

dataRow.name: The Broad
dataRow.description: The man-made lake (broad) on campus is a beautiful place to collect your thoughts and enjoy nature

dataRow.name: The Drama Studio
dataRow.description: The purpose-built 200-seat studio theatre plays host to professional productions, as well as regularly showcasing the work of students studying Drama at UEA.

dataRow.name: The Hive
dataRow.description: The Hive Bar, situated downstairs in Union House is used in many different ways; as a daytime cafe, a night-time venue for societies and as the second room on our regular student nights.

dataRow.name: The Square
dataRow.description: The Square is located at the heart of the University and a central focal point for the University community. It has recently been regenerated to include new paving, seating and a new central fountain and water feature.

dataRow.name: The Street
dataRow.description: On the Street you’ll find a variety of shops including our large food store (complete with Post Office), a Waterstones book shop and Cafe Direct coffee shop. Other facilities on The Street include a bank and a 24-hour laundrette. There’s also CareerCentral (https://www.uea.ac.uk/careers) the one-stop-shop for anything relating to careers.

dataRow.name: University Dental Service
dataRow.description: University Dental Service

dataRow.name: Interdisciplinary Institute
dataRow.description: The Interdisciplinary Institute for the Humanities is the home for the innovative Foundation Year in the Humanities and the Liberal Arts BA programme, as well as the MA in Creative Entrepreneurship. We provide an intellectual home for those activities in the Faculty of Arts and Humanities which cross disciplinary boundaries, including the Centre for Japanese Studies (CJS) and the East Anglian Film Archive (EAFA).

dataRow.name: Print Services
dataRow.description: Providing a high quality, professional printing service located within Building 18, Suffolk Road

dataRow.name: Safety Services
dataRow.description: Our role is to provide all staff and students at UEA with advice and guidance on safety

Term Time: Every Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday 10.00 am until 2.30 pm
Vacation Period: Tuesday only 10.00 – 2.30 pm

dataRow.name: Arts Hub
dataRow.description: For students from AMA, DEV, ECO, HIS, LAW, LDC, PPL studying UG and PG taught courses

dataRow.name: Elizabeth Fry Hub
dataRow.description: For students from BIO, CHE, CMP, ENV, MED, MTH, NBS, PHA, SCI studying UG and PG taught courses

dataRow.name: ZICER Hub
dataRow.description: For students from HSC, EDU, SWK, PSY studying UG and PG taught courses and placements

dataRow.name: Postgraduate Research Service (PGR)
dataRow.description: Postgraduate Research (PGR) provision at the University includes research programmes leading to Masters by Research (MA and MSc), Master of Philosophy (MPhil), Doctor of Philosophy (PhD) and other research-based qualifications across a range of subjects.

dataRow.name: University Medical Services
dataRow.description: UEA houses a Medical Centre to facilitate the students on its campus.
dataRow.openingtimes: Mon 0830-1830 hrs Tue 0830-2000 hrs Wed 0830-1830 hrs Thu 0830-1830 hrs Fri 0830-1830 hrs Sat 0830-1200 hrs Pre-booked appointments only

dataRow.name: Draped Reclining Woman
dataRow.description: Draped Reclining Woman. Henry Moore (1898-1986). England. 1957-58. Bronze, edition 4/6. w. 205 cm. Acquired from the artist 1960. Robert and Lisa Sainsbury Collection. UEA 86.

dataRow.name: One for Bristol
dataRow.description: One for Bristol, John Hoskin (1921-1990), England, 1968, Stainless steel, painted steel, University General & Vice-Chancellor's Collection UEA 41399

dataRow.name: Proximity
dataRow.description: Ian Tyson, Proximity, 2006, Painted steel, University Collection of Abstract and Constrctivist Art, Gifted by Anne Dilman in memory of her late husband Professor Ilham Dilman, UEA 31418

dataRow.name: Reclining Figure
dataRow.description: Reclining Figure. Henry Moore (1898-1986). England. 1956-62. Bronze, edition 4/8. w. 228 cm. Acquired from the artist 1962. Robert and Lisa Sainsbury Collection. UEA 85.

dataRow.name: Sculpture 1964 ("Variations on a Square")
dataRow.description: Sculpture 1964. Henry Clyne. 1964. Brass, brazed copper, steel. Acquired 1964. UEA 41289
Gender Neutral Toilets: 214/2.48, 214/2.29
Gender Neutral Toilets: 17/01.13 (12 toilets), 17/0.13 (14 toilets), 17/0.22 (13 toilets)

dataRow.name: Blackdale new student residence
dataRow.description: Development of the Blackdale site for a 514 study-bedroom student residence (Phase 1). Commenced June 2015 with an anticipated completion in September 2016. Senior Estates Project Manager: Martin Lovatt. Enquiries to: blackdale.development@uea.ac.uk

dataRow.name: Music Refurbishment
dataRow.description: Refurbishment of space including development of new media suite. Estates contact: richard.loveland@uea.ac.uk

dataRow.name: Thermal Stores
dataRow.description: Installation of heat storage cylinders. Estates contact: neil.wilson@uea.ac.uk

dataRow.name: Library LV Panel Change
dataRow.description: Essential electrical work over the Christmas period. Library closed from 7pm on 27 Dec to 12 noon on 2 Jan. Estates contact: p.thacker@uea.ac.uk

dataRow.name: Sportspark
dataRow.description: A new indoor cycle studio and physiotherapy clinic. 9th November to mid December.
